incomeBrackets.label: Working Poor
incomeBrackets.description: It's a grind. Every dollar is stretched. Ramen is practically a currency.

incomeBrackets.label: Low Income
incomeBrackets.description: Budgeting is an art form. A night out is a rare, celebrated event.

incomeBrackets.label: Lower Middle Class
incomeBrackets.description: Essentials are covered, maybe a concert. Saving is tough but not impossible.

incomeBrackets.label: Middle Class
incomeBrackets.description: Comfortable, but mindful of spending. Starting to build that nest egg.

incomeBrackets.label: Upper Middle Class
incomeBrackets.description: Life's pretty good! More treats, less stress. Investments are growing.

incomeBrackets.label: Affluent
incomeBrackets.description: Enjoying the finer things. Mountain getaways are a regular occurrence.

incomeBrackets.label: High Income
incomeBrackets.description: Luxury choices become normal. Hello, Cherry Creek North without wincing!

incomeBrackets.label: Wealthy
incomeBrackets.description: Premium experiences are the standard. Your financial advisor is a good friend.

incomeBrackets.label: Very Wealthy
incomeBrackets.description: Elite living. 'Fly commercial or private?' is a genuine dilemma.

incomeBrackets.label: Ultra High Net Worth
incomeBrackets.description: Exclusive access. Your hobbies sound like movie plots.

incomeBrackets.label: Millionaire
incomeBrackets.description: Congrats, you made it! Now, the fun part: smart allocation.

incomeBrackets.label: Multi-Millionaire
incomeBrackets.description: Private jet to Aspen for a quick bite? Sure, why not.

incomeBrackets.label: Ultra Wealthy
incomeBrackets.description: The world is your playground. You might own the playground manufacturer.

incomeBrackets.label: Ultra Elite
incomeBrackets.description: Your biggest worry? Which continent for the summer. Philanthropy is a passion.

incomeBrackets.label: Billionaire Class
incomeBrackets.description: Price tags are suggestions. Next stop: influencing global change (or Mars).

items.title: Home Cook Hero (by necessity!)
items.desc: Pasta, rice, beans are staples. King Soopers' generic brands are gold. A rare splurge: a $5 Little Caesars pizza.
items.financialNote: Savings are aspirational.

items.title: Grocery Ninja
items.desc: $150-200/month. Couponing isn't just a hobby, it's a lifestyle. Eating out is a dream.

items.title: Casual Eats & Local Haunts
items.desc: Hitting up Old Chicago or Santiago's for that green chili fix a few times a month. You're a happy hour connoisseur.

items.title: Smart Grocery Runs
items.desc: $400/month at King Soopers or Safeway. Maybe some organic produce if it's on sale.
items.financialNote: Slowly building an emergency fund.

items.title: Denver Foodie Adventures
items.desc: Weekly dinners in RiNo (Denver Central Market is a fave) or Tennyson St. Craft brews at Ratio or Odell are a weekend ritual.

items.title: Premium Pantry Stocking
items.desc: $600+/month. Regular Whole Foods or Trader Joe's trips. You invest in the good olive oil and artisanal bread.
items.financialNote: Maxing out that 401k feels good.

items.title: Fine Dining Connoisseur
items.desc: Regular reservations at Frasca, Beckon, or a power steak at Guard and Grace. Wine pairings are non-negotiable.

items.title: Gourmet Home Experience
items.desc: $1500+/month on food & wine. Marczyk Fine Foods is your second home. Perhaps a fancy Gaggenau oven.
items.financialNote: Diversified investments managed by a pro.

items.title: Private Chef & Exclusive Tables
items.desc: Personal chef for special occasions or weekly meal prep. Access to private dining rooms at top establishments.

items.title: Curated Wine Cellar
items.desc: Investing in rare and fine wines, possibly with a consultant. Trips to Napa or Bordeaux for 'research'.
items.financialNote: Estate planning and philanthropic strategies are key.

items.title: Roommate Shuffle
items.desc: Renting a room in an older building, maybe Aurora or Commerce City. Fingers crossed for compatible roommates!

items.title: Furniture Finds
items.desc: Mostly thrift store treasures (ARC, Goodwill) or generous hand-me-downs. You're a DIY wizard.
items.financialNote: Rent eats up a significant portion of income.

items.title: Your Own Cozy Corner
items.desc: Studio or 1BR in Cap Hill, Baker, or Englewood for ~$1800-$2200/month. Small, but all yours!

items.title: IKEA & Target Style
items.desc: Assembling flat-pack furniture is a rite of passage. That KALLAX shelf is a modern marvel.
items.financialNote: A down payment seems like a distant mountain.

items.title: Homeownership Horizons
items.desc: Eyeing a $450k-$550k townhome or starter home in Sloans Lake, or Arvada for more square footage.

items.title: West Elm & CB2 Aspirations
items.desc: Upgrading furniture. Maybe a brand-new couch that doesn't smell like someone else's dog!
items.financialNote: Mortgage, property taxes, and HOA fees are real.

items.title: Luxury Denver Living
items.desc: $1.2M+ home in Wash Park, Bonnie Brae, or a sleek modern build in LoHi. Heated bathroom floors? Yes, please.

items.title: Designer Touches & Renovations
items.desc: Working with an interior designer. Custom cabinetry and art investments. That dream kitchen is happening.
items.financialNote: Real estate as a significant asset class.

items.title: Multiple Luxury Properties
items.desc: Primary residence in Cherry Creek North, a ski chalet in Vail or Aspen, maybe a beach house somewhere warm.

items.title: Custom Architecture & Staff
items.desc: Commissioning an architect for a bespoke home. Full-time household staff including a house manager.
items.financialNote: Complex property management and tax considerations.

items.title: RTD All-Star
items.desc: You've mastered the bus and light rail. Walking and a trusty (if rusty) bike are your companions. You know the Cherry Creek trail detours.

items.title: The 'Character' Car
items.desc: If you own a car, it's a late 90s classic that cost <$3k and has its own unique soundtrack. You're a YouTube mechanic.
items.financialNote: Gas and insurance are major budget items.

items.title: Reliable Used Wheels
items.desc: $15-20K for a dependable used Honda Civic, Toyota Corolla, or an older Subaru to chase those mountain dreams.

items.title: Ride-Share Regular
items.desc: Uber/Lyft for those nights out when parking is a beast or you've sampled Denver's craft beer scene.
items.financialNote: Car payments are a line item, but manageable.

items.title: That New(ish) Car Scent
items.desc: $35-45K for a new Subaru Outback/Forester (hello I-70!), a Honda CR-V, or a zippy Mazda CX-5.

items.title: Worry-Free Maintenance
items.desc: Regular dealer services, comprehensive insurance. That check engine light causes less panic.
items.financialNote: Leasing vs. buying is a dinner table debate.

items.title: Luxury Commuting
items.desc: $80K+ vehicles. Tesla Model Y/S, BMW X5, Audi Q7, or a Porsche Macan for navigating Cherry Creek with style.

items.title: The Two-Car (or more) Household
items.desc: A practical daily driver plus a 'fun' weekend car â€“ perhaps a convertible or a classic Bronco for mountain adventures.
items.financialNote: Vehicle depreciation is factored into financial planning.

items.title: Exotic Car Collection
items.desc: Ferraris, Lamborghinis, McLarens. Maybe a bespoke Rolls-Royce or Bentley for comfortable cruising.

items.title: Private Driver / Chauffeur
items.desc: Full-time chauffeur for daily transport and errands. Never worry about parking again.
items.financialNote: Managing a fleet and staff requires expertise.

items.title: Staycation Pro
items.desc: Denver's parks (Wash Park, City Park), free museum days. Camping at Chatfield or Cherry Creek State Park is the annual big adventure.

items.title: Roadtrip Co-Pilot
items.desc: Chipping in for gas if a friend with a car is heading to the mountains or a nearby state. You bring the snacks!
items.financialNote: A 'vacation fund' is more like a 'maybe someday' jar.

items.title: Budget Domestic Explorer
items.desc: Annual flight on Southwest or Frontier. Weekend trips to Vegas, Phoenix, or visiting family. Budget-friendly Airbnbs.

items.title: Colorado Mountain Escapes
items.desc: Driving to Estes Park, Breckenridge (hello mud season deals!), or Salida for a weekend. Camping is still a favorite.
items.financialNote: Saving for trips involves careful planning.

items.title: International Adventures Begin
items.desc: First trips to Mexico, Canada, or maybe even a well-planned week in Europe (think hostels or budget hotels).

items.title: Comfortable Domestic Travel
items.desc: Flying major airlines (not basic economy!), staying in mid-tier hotels like Hilton or Marriott. Maybe a ski trip with friends.
items.financialNote: Dedicated travel savings account.

items.title: Business Class & Luxury Resorts
items.desc: Flying business class internationally. Staying at 5-star resorts in Hawaii, the Caribbean, or Europe. Maybe a luxury cruise.

items.title: Adventure & Experiential Travel
items.desc: Safaris in Africa, exploring Patagonia, or a cultural immersion trip to Southeast Asia. Unique experiences are prioritized.
items.financialNote: Travel agent or concierge service for planning.

items.title: First Class & Private Aviation
items.desc: Flying first class on premier airlines. Fractional ownership of a private jet (NetJets, Flexjet) or chartering for convenience.

items.title: World-Circling Itineraries
items.desc: Extended trips to multiple continents. Owning a vacation home abroad. Exclusive access to remote destinations.
items.financialNote: Global travel logistics and currency management.

items.title: Free Fun Seeker
items.desc: Denver Public Library for everything. Free concerts at Levitt Pavilion. Hiking Table Mesa in Golden. Netflix via a 'borrowed' account?

items.title: DIY Entertainment
items.desc: Drawing, writing, learning an instrument from YouTube tutorials. Imagination is your biggest budget item.
items.financialNote: Cable TV is a forgotten luxury.

items.title: Local Gigs & Games
items.desc: Catching a band at the Bluebird or Ogden. A Rockies game (the Rockpile still counts!). Movies at Alamo Drafthouse. A couple of streaming services.

items.title: Happy Hour Hero
items.desc: Meeting friends for drinks and apps is your social life. You're a connoisseur of $5 margarita deals and half-price wing nights.
items.financialNote: Entertainment budget: $100-$200/month.

items.title: Red Rocks & Major League Action
items.desc: Scoring tickets to a Red Rocks show (even if it means constant refreshing). Regular Avs or Nuggets games. Maybe a ski pass (Epic or Ikon).

items.title: Quality Home Entertainment
items.desc: A decent sound system, a new gaming console (PS5/Xbox Series X). Subscribing to ALL the streaming services.
items.financialNote: Hobbies start getting dedicated budget lines.

items.title: VIP & Season Tickets
items.desc: VIP packages for concerts. Season tickets for your favorite Denver sports team. Maybe a membership at a private social club.

items.title: High-End Hobbies
items.desc: Collecting art, fine wines, or vintage guitars. Golf memberships at exclusive clubs like Cherry Hills or Castle Pines.
items.financialNote: Discretionary spending is significant.

items.title: Courtside & Backstage Access
items.desc: Courtside seats at Ball Arena. Backstage passes to meet your favorite artists. Attending exclusive events like the Telluride Film Festival.

items.title: Funding the Arts / Owning a Team
items.desc: Becoming a patron of the Denver Art Museum or DCPA. Investing in Broadway shows. Maybe even part-ownership of a minor league team.
items.financialNote: Legacy building through cultural contributions.

items.title: Public Library University
items.desc: Denver Public Library is your campus. Free online courses (Coursera, edX) for skill-building. Khan Academy is your tutor.

items.title: Self-Taught & Resourceful
items.desc: Learning through podcasts, documentaries, and extensive internet research. Mentorship from experienced friends or colleagues.
items.financialNote: Formal education costs are prohibitive.

items.title: Community College / In-State Public Uni
items.desc: Community College of Denver or Metro State for affordable degrees/certs. CU Denver or CSU (in-state tuition) with student loans.

items.title: Trade Schools & Certifications
items.desc: Focusing on practical skills for specific careers through programs like Emily Griffith Technical College.
items.financialNote: Managing student loan debt is a priority.

items.title: Choice of Public or Private University
items.desc: Attending University of Denver (DU) or Colorado College with scholarships/loans. Out-of-state public universities become an option.

items.title: Continuing Education & Workshops
items.desc: Investing in professional development courses, industry conferences, and specialized workshops to advance career.
items.financialNote: Paying down student loans aggressively.

items.title: Elite Universities & Grad School
items.desc: Ivy League or other top-tier universities for undergrad or graduate programs (MBA, Law, Medicine) without crippling debt.

items.title: Private Tutors & Specialized Coaching
items.desc: Hiring tutors for children's challenging subjects. Executive coaching for career advancement. Language immersion programs.
items.financialNote: Setting up 529 plans for children's education.

items.title: Global Education & Bespoke Learning
items.desc: Sending children to elite international boarding schools (Switzerland, UK). Custom-designed educational programs and experiences.

items.title: University Donations & Endowments
items.desc: Significant philanthropic contributions to alma mater or other institutions. Funding research or scholarships. Maybe a building named after you.
items.financialNote: Establishing educational foundations or trusts.

items.title: The Ultimate DIY-er
items.desc: You cut your own hair (YouTube tutorials are a lifesaver!), clean your own everything, and are a pro at assembling IKEA furniture solo.

items.title: Community Support System
items.desc: Relying on friends for help with moves or pet-sitting. Bartering skills with neighbors.
items.financialNote: Paid personal services are a rare luxury.

items.title: Basic Maintenance Services
items.desc: Haircuts at Great Clips or Supercuts. Maybe a TaskRabbit for help with a heavy lifting job once a year.

items.title: Occasional House Cleaner
items.desc: Treating yourself to a house cleaning service (e.g., Molly Maid) before a big party or once every few months.
items.financialNote: Budgeting for small service conveniences.

items.title: Regular Pampering & Assistance
items.desc: Monthly haircuts at a decent salon (e.g., Floyd's 99). Bi-weekly house cleaning. Lawn care service during summer.

items.title: Personal Trainer & Wellness
items.desc: Gym membership with access to personal trainers (e.g., Chuze Fitness, Vasa). Maybe a ClassPass subscription for variety.
items.financialNote: Investing in personal well-being.

items.title: Concierge Lifestyle
items.desc: Personal assistant (part-time) for errands and scheduling. Premium spa treatments (e.g., The Woodhouse Day Spa). Personal shopper for wardrobe updates.

items.title: Household Support Staff
items.desc: Full-time nanny if you have children. Regular landscaping and pool maintenance. Dog walker and pet groomer.
items.financialNote: Managing payroll for domestic staff.

items.title: Full Estate Management
items.desc: Butler, private chef, full-time housekeeping staff, groundskeepers, personal security detail. A dedicated estate manager oversees operations.

items.title: Bespoke Global Services
items.desc: Access to world-class service professionals on demand, anywhere in the world. 24/7 concierge for any request imaginable.
items.financialNote: Services budget is a significant portion of overall expenses.
